title: English coach who almost got caught up in a civil war wants job in club football
text:

From the day professional football was born, managers have been dealing with as many off-the-field problems as on it.

Angry bookmakers and angrier husbands have long wanted pieces of players of the years, and over the years so many star names have managed to get caught up in bar-room brawls.

Such matters can seem trivial, however, when you’ve managed players who are facing the outbreak of civil war - which is just one of the situations Englishman Stephen Constantine has found himself in during an incredibly eclectic career.

Constantine, a FIFA elite coach who has managed the national teams of India, twice, Nepal, Malawi, Sudan and Rwanda, as well as club sides in Cyprus, said: “Sudan was obviously really challenging.

“The situation at the time was not great — I went when an arrest warrant was issued for Omar al-Bashir, the Prime Minister, and civil war was about to break out.

(Image: AFP)

“Luckily it didn’t.

“On the field, the team was an old one that was set in its ways and getting them to try to play was a challenge.

“We were only there for six games before all hell broke loose politically but we managed to do it.

“With Rwanda, we qualified for the group stages of the Africa Cup of Nations despite it being extremely challenging — bad fields, the balls weren’t good, the kit wasn’t good.

(Image: REUTERS)

“But football is football, you play 11 versus 11 and you play on a level pitch — in most cases, anyway.

“A lot of people ask why I’ve taken the jobs I’ve taken but my response is, ‘Why not?

“I have had a choice: sit around and do nothing, do something other than what I love or go, and I chose to go.”

Now Constantine, a former first-team coach at Millwall, wants to stay, and after taking India from 173 in the FIFA rankings to 97 he would love a return to club football.

He added: “It’s about managing people wherever you are.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

“Players want to know how you’re going to make them better and, if they want, I will do it.

“There’s no player who can’t improve something in their game, but only if they want to - that is the key.

“Now I’m looking for a chairman who is thinking outside the box.

“I need them to ask, ‘What does he bring to the table? Can he coach? Can he manage people? Has he won anything?’

“I got my pro license in England, I have proved I can manage people, I’ve won small tournaments at international level and I qualified for the Asian Cup with India, the equivalent of Iceland getting to the World Cup.

(Image: REUTERS)

“We won our first game 4-1, the first time they’d ever won a match in the Asian Cup.

“It’s not easy for chairmen because I understand it can be better the devil you know.

“Would a chairman sit down and consider all that when someone else has been at Portsmouth, Liverpool , here or there?

“But I hope one of them will take a chance. I am less of a risk than anyone else because I haven’t failed here yet and I will only get one shot.

“If I fail in my first job here then I won’t get another chance.”
description: Stephen Constantine fired India up the FIFA rankings and has also managed Sudan and Rwanda in tough situations
